citances.sentence: The conduct to which s.51AA refers is unconscionable conduct within the established principles of equity: Australian Competition & Consumer Commission v Samton Holdings Pty Ltd & Ors (2002) 117 FCR 301 ; Australian Competition & Consumer Commission v CG Berbatis Holdings Pty Ltd & Ors [2003] HCA 18 ; (2003) 214 CLR 51. In the common law the term "unconscionable" is used to describe various grounds of equitable intervention employed to refuse enforcement of, or to set aside, transactions which offend equity and good conscience: ACCC v CG Berbatis Holdings Pty Ltd at 72 [42] per Gummow and Hayne JJ. However, Matthew and Hollie do not seek relief of this nature. Their statement of claim does not identify any facts which amount to unconscionable conduct as understood by the unwritten law of Australia. Although the precise scope of the doctrine of unconscionability has not yet been determined, in circumstances where no allegation has been made of a relevant inequality of position or bargaining power, fraud, misrepresentation, unconscientious advantage being taken of unilateral mistake, or that the applicants were in a position of special vulnerability, the allegation of unconscionability under s.51AA cannot be made out. Matthew and Hollie's s.51AA claim is really no more than an allegation of unfairness arising out of a breach of contract. Such circumstances do not attract relief under the section: Body Bronze International Pty Ltd v Soleil Tanning Oxford Pty Ltd [2007] FCA 371. Unconscionable conduct --- Section 51AC
